metadata.title: LA-PHYS-2.5 Intro to Energy and Work
metadata.creator: jason_wang
metadata.abstract: This document is for testing purposes only. The material that is presented here should be treated as an example only.

stack.p: Although we often hear people talking about energy consumption, energy is never really destroyed. It is just transferred from one form to another, doing work in the process. In this module, we are going to learn the concept of energy and work, and how to measure them.
A block with mass 5kg is initially resting on a frictionless surface. Lift the block or/and push the block using the controller below and see the change of the energy and work.
1 Push = A force acts on the block for very short period 1 Lift = Lift the block by 1 metre
stack.script: local P = {box = plot.box, ground = plot.ground, length=4, center={20,4}, position={20,4}}

button.name: start
button.onClick: if start.Text == "Start Simulation" then start.Text = "Pause Simulation" sim:Play() else start.Text = "Start Simulation" sim:Pause() end

stack.script:
local PE = 0 local KE = 0 local m = 5 local g = 9.81 local v = 0
plotTools.drawSquare(P.ground, vector({20,1}), 40, 2)
function P:initDrawing() local hl = self.length/2 self.box:Add(self.center[1],self.center[2]) self.box:Add(self.center[1]-hl, self.center[2]-hl) self.box:Add(self.center[1]-hl, self.center[2]+hl) self.box:Add(self.center[1]+hl, self.center[2]+hl) self.box:Add(self.center[1]+hl, self.center[2]-hl) self.box:Add(self.center[1]-hl, self.center[2]-hl) end
function P:reset() PE = 0 KE = 0 v = 0 btns.simBtns.start.Text = "Start Simulation" self.position = {20,4} self.box.Transform = matrixf.translation(0,0,0) P:updateData() end
function P:lift() PE = PE + m*g self.position[2] = self.position[2] + 1 self.box.Transform = matrixf.translation(self.position[1] - self.center[1], self.position[2] - self.center[2], 0) self:updateData() end
function P:push() KE = KE + 50 v = math.sqrt(KE*2/m) self:updateData() end
function P:updatePosition() self.position[1] = self.position[1] + v/100 self.box.Transform = matrixf.translation(self.position[1] - self.center[1], self.position[2] - self.center[2], 0) end
function P:updateData() dataTable:Child(2):Child(1):Child(1).Text = string.format("%.2f", v) dataTable:Child(2):Child(2):Child(1).Text = string.format("%d", PE) dataTable:Child(2):Child(3):Child(1).Text = string.format("%d", KE) dataTable:Child(2):Child(4):Child(1).Text = string.format("%d", PE+KE) dataTable:Child(2):Child(5):Child(1).Text = string.format("%d", KE) end
P:initDrawing()

stack.p: Energy is a measurement of the ability of something to do work. It is not a material substance. Energy can be stored and measured in many forms. Energy is never really destroyed. It is just transferred from one form to another, doing work in the process.

A speeding bullet has a measurable amount of energy (Kinetic energy) associated with it. The bullet gained this energy because work was done on it by a charge of gunpowder which lost some chemical potential energy in the process.
In practice, whenever work is done to move energy from one form to another, there is always some loss to other forms of energy such as heat and sound.

In physics, a force is said to do work if, when acting, there is a displacement of the point of application in the direction of the force. For example, when a ball is held above the ground and then dropped, the work done on the ball as it falls is equal to the weight of the ball (a force) multiplied by the distance to the ground (a displacement).
The work $\,W$ done by a constant force of magnitude $\,F$ on a point that moves a displacement $\,s$ in a straight line in the direction of the force is the product
The standard unit used to measure energy and work done in physics is the Joule, which has the symbol J. In mechanics, $1J = 1N \cdot m$.

Another unit of energy is Calorie. The amount of energy in an item of food is often written in Calories on the back of the packet. One Calorie is the amount of energy required to raise 1 kg of water by 1 °C.

sectionNoTitle.script: local stepsController = StepsController:new({stepsStack=stepsStack, numOfSteps=4, shown_message="Show Step", hidden_message="Hide Step", showStepCounter=true})

stack.p: Suppose we're feeling guilty about eating a chocolate bar; we want to find how much exercise we need to do to burn off those extra 200 Calories. Let's consider a simple form of exercise: pushing a heavy box around a room, see Figure below.

stack.name: cont
stack.p: The work we need to do to burn the energy in the candy bar is

stack.name: cont
stack.p: Using Work equation: $W=F \cdot \Delta x$, we can calculate $\Delta x$

stack.name: cont
stack.p: What if the box was pulled in an angle like below:

In the case of the box shown above, only the horizontal component of the applied force, $Fcos(\theta)$, left parenthesis, theta, right parenthesis, is doing work on the box since the box is being displaced horizontally.
Now a more general equation can be written as:
If the applied force is 500N with an angle of 30 degree. How much of a chocolate bar can we eat this time if we pull the box through the same 1673.6 m?

stack.name: cont
stack.p: Another common form of exercise is lifting weights. In this case we are working against the force of gravity rather than friction.
We can determine the force $F = mg$, and the change in position is simply the height, so the work is
If lifting 50kg weight to a height of 0.5m, the work done to the weight is

sectionNoTitle.script: local stepsController = StepsController:new({stepsStack=stepsStack, numOfSteps=8, shown_message="Show Step", hidden_message="Hide Step", showStepCounter=true})

stack.p: Someone moves a 5kg box to the right with a force of 50N, the force of kinetic friction while it's sliding is 30N. The box slides the ground for a distance of 10 metres. What's the work done by each force? What's the net work? How fast is the box after moving 10m?

stack.name: cont
stack.p: The distance $\,d = 10m$, the $\,F$ and the angle between that force and the displacement, $\,\theta$ is going to differ for each of the forces.

stack.name: cont
stack.p: To find the net work done on this box, we simple add up all the works done by individual forces:

stack.name: cont
stack.p: From the work-energy principle, we have

stack.name: cont
stack.p: If we lift the box upward for 2 metres with constant velocity, what's the net work done on the box?
This makes sense, because there is no kinetic energy change, in other word, $\Delta KE = 0$

column.p: Hans Full is pulling on a rope to drag his backpack to school across the ice. He pulls upwards and rightwards with a force of 22.9 Newtons at an angle of 35 degrees above the horizontal to drag his backpack a horizontal distance of 129 metres to the right. Determine the work (in Joules) done upon the backpack.

textField.name: input
textField.placeholder: Enter your answer here. (round to nearest integer)

button.name: btn
button.onClick: if input.Text ~= answer.Text then feedback.Style.Visibility = "visible" feedback.Text = "Incorrect! Try again." attempt = attempt + 1 if attempt >= max then answerStack.Style.Visibility = "visible" end else feedback.Style.Visibility = "visible" feedback.Text = "Correct, Good Job!" end

column.p: While training for breeding season, a 380 gram male squirrel does 32 pushups in a minute, displacing its center of mass by a distance of 8.5 cm for each pushup. Determine the total work done on the squirrel while moving upward (32 times).

textField.name: input
textField.placeholder: Enter your answer here. (round to nearest integer)

button.name: btn
button.onClick: if input.Text ~= answer.Text then feedback.Style.Visibility = "visible" feedback.Text = "Incorrect! Try again." attempt = attempt + 1 if attempt >= max then answerStack.Style.Visibility = "visible" end else feedback.Style.Visibility = "visible" feedback.Text = "Correct, Good Job!" end

column.p: Justin Thyme is traveling down Lake Avenue at 32.8 m/s in his 1510-kg 1992 Camaro. He spots a police car with a radar gun and quickly slows down to a legal speed of 20.1 m/s.
a. Determine the initial kinetic energy of the Camaro. b. Determine the kinetic energy of the Camaro after slowing down. c. Determine the amount of work done on the Camaro during the deceleration.

textField.name: input
textField.placeholder: Enter your answer here. (round to nearest integer)

textField.name: input2
textField.placeholder: Enter your answer here. (round to nearest integer)

textField.name: input3
textField.placeholder: Enter your answer here. (round to nearest integer)

button.name: btn
button.onClick: if input.Text ~= answer.Text or input2.Text ~= answer2.Text or input3.Text ~= answer3.Text then feedback.Style.Visibility = "visible" feedback.Text = "Incorrect! Try again." attempt = attempt + 1 if attempt >= max then answerStack.Style.Visibility = "visible" end else feedback.Style.Visibility = "visible" feedback.Text = "Correct, Good Job!" end

column.p: Sheila (m=56.8 kg) is in her saucer sled moving at 12.6 m/s at the bottom of the sledding hill near Bluebird Lake. She approaches a long embankment inclined upward at 16° above the horizontal. As she slides up the embankment, she encounters a coefficient of friction of 0.128. Determine the height to which she will travel before coming to rest.
